content.description: Start in the right-facing dihedral. Climb the corner to rest. Forge out to the right through a pebbly band to a diagonal ramp. Climb past the ledge to the Anchors.
content.location: The obvious dihedral in the middle of the left main wall.

climbs.name: Two Cam Sam
climbs.fa: E. Whittemore, M. Cartwright, 3/86; FFA: E. Whittemore, 10/89

content.description: Power through a rounded roof with holes to a stance to access the crux bulge. Climb past 3 bolts and gun for the Mussy Hooks!
content.protection: Glue In Bolts and Mussy Hook Anchors
content.location: It's the first route as you round the trail under the roof and glimpse the left main wall.

climbs.name: Tuff Enuff
climbs.fa: FA: M. Cartwright, solo Feb 1986, FA E. Whittemore May 1989

content.description: Thin technical 5.11 climbing from the ground to restful clipping holds at bolt 3. The crux is a crux sequence between bolts 3 and 4 through a shallow dihedral in pristine white rock.
content.location: see picture. right of 2 cam sam, left of judy's world.

climbs.name: Three Teeth
climbs.fa: First ascent unknown, done in the late '60's

content.description: Climb up the wide cracks passing ramps and large blocks to a ledge. Continue on through the corner via the steep crack and bucket climbing
content.protection: Trad with Top Anchors.  Can reach Anchors from the Overlook to Rappel and Top Rope
content.location: Start at the base of a ramp in a large, right-facing dihedral below and right of the Headwall.

content.description: Slabby friction moves lead up a short rounded ledge.
content.location: Start on a rounded overlap about 70' right of where the gully trail meets the rock of the Lower Cliff and where the trail goes around a tree. To set up the top rope, keep going straight down a series of ledges until you find the ring anchors at the end of the cliff.

climbs.name: Summit Attempt
climbs.fa: Ed Marshall or A. Ilgner, M. Cartwright)

content.description: Climb up deceivingly difficult cracks and face to the right terrace below the Headwall. Sneak up the moderate rock to an awkward finish on the exposed Headwall. A real classic.
content.protection: Ten bolts and Fixed Anchors at the Summit
content.location: Start on the left face of the MOTHER WALL buttress. 30' right of the approach slabs.

climbs.name: Sail Rabbits
climbs.fa: E. Whittemore, M. Ilgner, 1/86; FFA: E. Whittemore, D. Parsons, 10/88

content.description: Cruise up the blocks to a small ledge. From the ledge, crank past 2 bolts to a series of overlapping horizontals to the anchors.
content.location: Startup at first bolted route left of the bolted arete on the far right of the wall.

content.description: Climb up the outside corner to the bolt and head straight up the rounded arete. Pass 2 bolts, some holes, and clever laybacks to anchors on the ledge.
content.location: Start about 70' right of the big dihedral on a right-facing, outside corner on a blunt arete.

content.description: Start ramps and flakes below a thin-hands crack. Hard face climbing leads to the crack. Cruise up the crack to a bulge. Pass the bulge on the left side and climb up to the anchors below the ledge.
content.location: Middle of the first section of the left main wall

content.description: Start on the left side of the right chimney in the big, open corner. Climb the cracks inside the chimney up to the anchors below the bulge of the Overlook.
content.location: The far-right side of the Left Main wall.

content.description: A gentle slab climb past 4 bolts to anchors on a big ledge at the base of the headwall
content.protection: four bolts and two top anchors
content.location: On the trail halfway between the main left wall and the right wall.

content.description: Bee Rock is considered the first developed climbing area of the Cumberland Plateau. It was climbed back in the early 70’s using aid climbing techniques. The first ascents for free climbing were done by legends Frank Sanders, Eddie Whittemore, Mark Cartwright, Arno Ilgner. The routes are good-quality sandstone. The cliff is easy to access and very conveniently located 5 minutes from the Monterey exit on I40. It became a popular destination for Tennessee Tech students in the 80’s because they could leave their dorm room and be at Bee in 15 minutes.
